title: Prognostic Index for Cancer Outcomes
description: Predicts cancer mortality from serum biomarkers using C-reactive protein (CRP) and white blood cell (WBC) count. This simple two-parameter scoring system provides risk stratification for cancer patients and helps guide prognostic discussions and clinical decision-making across multiple cancer types.

result.name: prognostic_index_score
result.description: Prognostic index score predicting cancer mortality risk based on inflammatory markers

ranges.interpretation: Good prognosis with minimal systemic inflammatory response. Both CRP and WBC count are within normal ranges, suggesting less aggressive disease and better potential outcomes.
Intermediate prognosis with moderate systemic inflammatory response. Either elevated CRP or elevated WBC count indicates some degree of inflammation associated with cancer progression.
Poor prognosis with significant systemic inflammatory response. Both CRP and WBC count are elevated, indicating substantial inflammation and potentially more aggressive disease with worse outcomes.

references: Proctor MJ, McMillan DC, Morrison DS, Fletcher CD, Horgan PG, Clarke SJ. A derived neutrophil to lymphocyte ratio predicts survival in patients with cancer. Br J Cancer. 2012;107(4):695-9. doi: 10.1038/bjc.2012.292.

Proctor MJ, Morrison DS, Talwar D, Balmer SM, Fletcher CD, O'Reilly DS, et al. A comparison of inflammation-based prognostic scores in patients with cancer. A Glasgow Inflammation Outcome Study. Eur J Cancer. 2011;47(17):2633-41. doi: 10.1016/j.ejca.2011.03.028.
McMillan DC. The systemic inflammation-based Glasgow Prognostic Score: a decade of experience in patients with cancer. Cancer Treat Rev. 2013;39(5):534-40. doi: 10.1016/j.ctrv.2012.08.003.
formula: Score = CRP points + WBC points (where CRP >10 mg/L = 1 point, WBC >11 × 10⁹/L = 1 point)
notes: Simple two-parameter scoring system using readily available laboratory values
Validated across multiple cancer types and patient populations
Higher scores indicate worse prognosis due to increased systemic inflammation
Should be used in conjunction with other prognostic factors and clinical judgment
CRP reflects acute-phase response and tumor-associated inflammation
Elevated WBC count may indicate immune response to cancer or infection
Not a standalone diagnostic tool - requires integration with staging and other factors
Survival outcomes vary significantly depending on cancer type, stage, and treatment
May help guide prognostic discussions and treatment planning decisions
Regular monitoring of these biomarkers may help track disease progression
Cost-effective prognostic tool using standard laboratory tests
Particularly useful in settings where more complex scoring systems are unavailable
